posts.com:
If I insert something into a SQL table, do I need to list every fuckin row column in the php query like this:

>$query = "INSERT into phpbb3.phpbb_users (user_type, group_id, user_permissions, user_perm_from, user_ip, user_regdate, username....

There are 70 columns and I just want to insert a new user without adding some value in every colum

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300285
Afaik you just skip column names that you don't want to insert data into. Only the primary key is needed to be inserted. When you create the table you can use DEFAULT keyword to specify a default value in a column if you need to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300285
Depends on how the sql table is made, if the data you want to ommit is made to accept null, then you can just add the fields you are going to use, and their values.

>INSERT INTO phpbb3.phpbb_users (user_type, username) VALUES ('admin', 'JOHN DOE')

if the ommited values accept null, then they will be inserted as null by default.

You can also set a default value on the table structure if you don't want it to be null (that must be done from the sql client, with alter table).
https://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_alter.asp

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300285
Pretty sure PHPBB has its own user-adding form that provides a GUI and takes care of all the fields when an authenticated user with permission wants to add another user.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299013
For example, if you run the script
>yt-dlp --download-archive archive.txt https://www.youtube.com/@bisnap/videos
then the program will (1) download all the videos on that page and (2) record all the IDs of the downloaded videos in the file archive.txt. If you run the same script again (e. g., through a daily cron job), then the program will skip downloading any videos whose IDs are already listed in archive.txt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299017
And, if you've already downloaded a bunch of videos prior to beginning to use the "download-archive" option, you can use the "dateafter" option to filter stuff that was uploaded before a certain date.

posts.com:
>>1300089
I think you got the wrong thread/board.

Anyways, the problem isn't the conceptual design of a projectile-style physics package, anyone with an engineering degree could make one of those, the problem is enriching Uranium. You can do that in one of three ways:
- in a breeder reactor, the downside of which being you need to already have enriched uranium and a nuclear reactor
- in a Calutron, which is basically a factory-complex-sized mass-spectrometer. This is what was used in the Manhattan Project, and the whole process was so complicated and fascinating it's worth reading the whole thing: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calutron . Spoiler: they used 6,000 TONS of silver, because the war couldn't spare 6000 tons of copper
- centrifuging Uranium Tetrafluoride. This is how it's done nowadays. UTF is probably the worst chemical that can possibly exist, it's worth reading the Material Safety Data Sheet if you've got a thing for dark nerd humour. I particularly liked "Observe all Federal, State and local Regulations when disposing of this substance", given how it's controlled as a precursor to nuclear weapons, radioactive, poisonous (because of the uranium), poisonous (because of the fluorine), corrosive, carcinogenic, and borderline explosive.
https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2020/11/f80/SDS-Uranium_Hexafluoride_UF6_2020.pdf
You have to heat it until it's a gas, then centrifuge the gas. Heat it but don't let it catch fire, there's very few substances that will put it out. Water turns it into hydrofluoric acid, which will eat through your flesh, then react with your bones and turn your bones into poison. You need to do this with hundreds of tons of this stuff to get enough enriched uranium to make a gun-type warhead.

>explain my subtext to you
better yet, I'll explain to OP how to solve his problem

windows key + x, then press i to open a terminal
type python3 and press enter, the Windows store will open automatically and take you through an installation process

if you don't have ffmpeg installed, you need that too:
https://ffmpeg.org/download.html

then back in your terminal, paste this line and press enter:
pip install git+https://github.com/openai/whisper.git

then run this line:
whisper C:\Users\blah\audio.wav
change the path to wherever your audio file is

there, that's it.

also the article said you need to enable something like in the pic, but I've never seen that before.
when something goes wrong post a screenshot of it or paste the error message here

>>1300376
>Am I correct in thinking that as long as the motherboard has slots for everything I want that it doesn't really matter which one I go for or is there anything else I should be considering?
Processor features are now tied to what motherboard you purchased: the processor checks and disables them if you didn't pay enough.
Intel does this with overclocking: even with a K-processor, you can't fiddle with the multiplier unless you have a Z motherboard.
AMD does it with PCI Express: even though it's the CPU that generates high-speed PCIe lanes, the chipset isn't involved, and the motherboard's sole involvement is providing 40 pairs of wires, AMD processors will disable their PCIe 4.0/5.0 support if you didn't pay for at least a B550.

Anyways, what you should do is find someone who assembled a PC that they're happy with, and copy that. Or buy one from a local store.

>>1300432
>AMD processors will disable their PCIe 4.0/5.0 support if you didn't pay for at least a B550.
Some motherboard manufacturers tried adding support for PCIe 4.0 on X470/B450, but the signal wasn't stable enough, so they disabled it in the end.

>the motherboard's sole involvement is providing 40 pairs of wires
High speed digital signals are a bitch and a half to get right.
It's not just a matter of plugging wires together.
You need them all to be right length, the right width, as well as the right distance from the ground plane and one another.
If the PCB isn't engineered for PCIe 4.0 speeds, it's just not happening.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

Find a good game in the same genre that has good reviews, and copy it. Preferably one that's exclusive to the platform you're targeting. Nothing more annoying than xbox okay/cancel on a switch, or vice versa.

posts.com: How and from where do i start learning game development? How do you do it efficiently and how long can it take to get decent results?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You should start by defining "decent results"

Ideally you know how to program, and if not, you'll either have to learn at the same time as you learn game development, or else try to learn the basics of programming before you start learning game development. It's ideal to already know programming because it's going to be that much harder for you to grasp new concepts and design your own robust systems if you don't even know what a function is. If you already know some programming and have worked on some projects in the past then you already have a pretty big leg up

Unity has a lot of tutorials, like A LOT a lot, some of them good and some of them... well some of them just tell you to download plugins from the asset store, which hurts you more than helps you in the long run. If you chose to start with Unity, I recommend Ruby's 2D Adventure: https://learn.unity.com/project/ruby-s-2d-rpg
Because it's a small tutorial with easy to grasp concepts. Don't worry if you'd prefer to make 3D games, because it will give you enough to learn the basics of the engine and go your own way. There are a lot of 3D tutorials also.

If you don't want to use Unity then I don't know, I'm sure there are decent learning materials for other engines too. If you're especially cool and want to learn games programming "the spartan way" there is something called Raylib, which I really enjoy but is admittedly not for everyone: https://www.raylib.com/

Ultimately games development is about what you're willing to put into it and you have to be in it for life basically lol. It will take a lot out of you so you have to really want it unless you're content with making dumb little game jam demos. Approach it with a learner's mindset because you're always going to be learning new things even after your 3rd or 4th game release. There's just so much to learn, and halfway through every project, you're going to feel like dropping that project because you'll know that there's a better way to design it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299836
Pick up an engine to start. The two biggest "industry standard" game engines are Unreal Engine and Unity.
Typically programming and scripting is done in C++ for UE and C# for Unity.
Both engines have free plans and an abundance of documentation, online guides and tutorials to get you started.

However there's myriads more engines than just those 2.
Personally I like Godot. It's a a newer game engine that is completely open source and free. It's easier to pick up than the other 2 and has its own python-derived scripting language made specifically for game development, but you can also write your code in C# if you already know that or need the performance boost.
What I like the most about Godot is how easy it is to get into, and fast to work and iterate with, everything is in just one executable that launches in seconds.
However, it's not industry standard and there haven't been many big games made with it to "prove" it as a solid engine yet, and it's mode focused towards making 2D games, although the currently in beta version 4 of the engine has many big improvements to 3D.

You can freely experiment but I recommend following a book or a video tutorial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1299836
The way I went about it was making stuff from scratch at first - pick a very simple 2d graphics library (pygame or Swing come to mind), and just start making very small, very simple stuff. For example, start with snake (get comfortable thinking in the context of a game loop), a simple 2d roguelike, (mapping a 'model' grid into the 'view' of the game), then a simple platformer (simple high school physics, AABB collision). Granted, a modern game engine will make these things very easily - but the point of writing them from scratch is to switch your frame of reference. Once you feel comfortable with it, then start using an engine

posts.com:
A clock keeps accurate time at 10°C, but gains as the temperature falls and vice-versa, the rate of gain or loss varying as the square of the number of °C between the actual temperature and 10°C. If it gains 2 seconds per day when the temperature is 5°C, how much does it lose (to the nearest second) in 4 days when the temperature is 42°C?

I'm interpreting this as r = k/(t-10)^2

so 2 = k/(5-10)^2, k = 50

but am not getting anywhere near the solution of 328 seconds. What am I doing wrong?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300262
>A clock keeps accurate time at 10°C, but gains as the temperature falls and vice-versa,
>the rate of gain or loss varying as the square of the number of °C between the actual temperature and 10°C.
meaning dT/dt = k(T-10)^2
>If it gains 2 seconds per day when the temperature is 5°C,
dT/dt = 2s/day = k(5-10)^2
2 = k(25)
k = 2/25 s/day
so now we have the constant rate constant k, we can move on

>how much does it lose (to the nearest second) in 4 days when the temperature is 42°C?
first we find the rate of change per day dT/dt according to temp of 42, this will be in sec/day because that's the rate constant's unit
dT/dt = k(T-10)^2
dT/dt = 2/25 * (42-10)^2 sec/day
dT/dt = 2/25 * 1024 sec/day
dT/dt = 81.92 sec/day

next, multiply 4 days
total loss = 4 days x 81.92 sec/days
total loss = 328 s

that's all bro

- extract the app (another 3gb)
- then delete the download (minus 3gb)

posts.com:
The Hinomaru Sumo anime had two short episodes exclusive to the bluray releases: "夏だ!海だ!火ノ丸相撲!!", a beach episode loosely based on a manga volume extra, and pic related, "卒業相撲", an adaptation of the last few chapters from part 1.

Hinomaru Sumo is legitimately one of the slowest-selling anime of the last decade, so unsurprisingly I've never seen a rip of the BD/DVDs on the cat site or any private trackers I have access to, nor have I been able to find either episode on japanese streaming sites.

>b950 2c 2.1ghz , 4gb ram, intel hd graphics 2000
That's a Sandy Bridge Pentium, and it will run Windows 10 fine. Windows 10 is what you should put on it. Windows 10 on Sandy Bridge's onboard graphics and 4GB is absolutely fine, as fast as 7, or possibly faster.

If you want to spend some money on it, get a SATA SSD (you can get a brand new 240GB for $20). You can also get a Core i5 2540M for ~$30, but I don't recommend changing a processor unless you know what you're doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How do I enhance audio on a mp3 file in audacity? I am trying to help my family members win a lawsuit against a nursing home for medical malpractice and my mom sent me an audio file that she has asked me to edit so the conversations can be heard. (The recording was obtained in a 1 party consent state.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300085
Could you post a sample?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1300085
Find the parts that are actual conversation. Make a note of where they are hh:mm:ss as a reminder

Find periods of silence, no talking, no rustling cloths, passing traffic, etc. Good if it's a few seconds long but even half a second can be useful. Select one of these sections.

Go to Effect | Noise Removal and Repair | Noise Reduction...
Click on Step 1 Get Noise Profile
The dialogue box will close.

Then select a bit of the speaking section.
Go to Effect | Noise Removal and Repair | Noise Reduction...
Play around with the settings in Step 2 and test.

Then amplify the section you're working on
Go to Effect | Volume and Compression | Amplify...
Play around some more and test.

Then once you're happy, undo all the changes, like by closing the file and starting a new project. This time, instead of select some of the speaking, Select All and apply Step 2 of noise reduction and amplification to the whole track.

Sometimes, it's better to amplify first, then do both steps of noise reduction.

If you noise reduce too much you can end up with problems, like making people sound like the bubbling sound used on kids shows for people underwater or other things. Too much amplification will clip the sound and distort it. So test until you're happy. You can amplify one section at a time if you like and if recording conditions change, like maybe inside to outside it can sometimes help to noise reduce each section separately with a noise profile from a nearby time.

>>1300085
>(The recording was obtained in a 1 party consent state.)
We have literally no way of verifying this and the problem would be yours if it wasn't true. It's an unnecessary detail.

Be prepared that the opposing litigant will contest the legitimacy of your editing of the recording and a judge or jury will listen to this contest. They'll attack your credentials, of which you have none, and they could easily accuse you of tampering because you have no professional standing or code of practice to uphold.
